snippet: Through decades of repression, Syria’s capital held on to an atmosphere of tranquility, but the proximity of recent clashes has left residents afraid to leave their neighborhoods.
abstract: Proximity of clashes in suburbs of Syria's capital Damascus leaves residents afraid to leave their neighborhoods; violence so close to Pres Bashar al-Assad's stronghold is new development as Damascus had held on to atmosphere of tranquility.

byline.original: By an EMPLOYEE of THE NEW YORK TIMES in SYRIA and ANNE BARNARD
byline.contributor: An employee of The New York Times reported from Damascus, and Anne Barnard from Beirut, Lebanon. Neil MacFarquhar contributed reporting from Beirut.

lead_paragraph: Through decades of repression, Syria’s capital held on to an atmosphere of tranquility, but the proximity of recent clashes has left residents afraid to leave their neighborhoods.

headline.seo: Damascus Is Tested as Clashes Draw Near
headline.main:
Fighting Drives an
Old Sense of Peace
From Damascus
headline.print_headline: Peace in Damascus Is Tested As Nearby Clashes Draw Nearer

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
